headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Nvidia Beats, but Doesn't Wow
summary: Nvidia reported earnings that didn’t wow Wall Street, even though its quarterly revenue and outlook came in slightly above analyst forecasts.  The chip maker has regularly surprised Wall Street with its AI-fueled revenue and profit growth, but that didn’t happen Wednesday: Nvidia reported $46.7 billion of sales in its latest quarter versus a FactSet consensus of around $46 billion.  Nvidia’s shares fell in after-market trading.

Nvidia’s shares fell in after-market trading.

headline: AI bellwether Nvidia forecasts Q3 revenue above forecasts
summary: Helped by robust demand for its artificial intelligence chips from cloud providers expanding infrastructure to power generative AI technology, Nvidia expects revenue of $54 billion, plus or minus 2%, in the third quarter.  "PitchBook’s comp sheet analysis also shows hyperscalers and AI infrastructure leaders outperforming benchmarks, underscoring durable demand for compute hardware as governments and enterprises step up procurement."

headline: Stock markets waver before Nvidia reports profits climb
summary: Stock markets fluctuated Wednesday as investors braced for a key earnings update from AI giant Nvidia, whose robust growth has largely driven strong gains for tech stocks in recent months.Investors are now awaiting updates to US economic growth data due Thursday and a key inflation gauge Friday for clues on how far interest rates might fall in the coming months.

headline: Nvidia’s Data Center Revenue Soared in Second Quarter, but Still Misses Wall Street Estimate
summary: Start-ups and corporations are still clamoring for Nvidia’s AI data center chips.  The chip maker reported data center revenue of $41.1 billion in the July quarter, up 56% year over year.  “The strong year-on-year and sequential growth was driven by demand for our accelerated computing platform used for large language models, recommendation engines, and generative and agentic AI applications,” CFO Colette Kress said in a release.

headline: Nvidia Breaks Sales Record Despite Chinese Trade Hiccups
summary: Nvidia  set fresh sales records, as the world’s most valuable publicly traded company continued to capitalize on strong demand for AI computing power and shrugged off uncertainty surrounding its business in China.  The company predicted revenue of $54 billion for the third quarter, slightly higher than consensus estimates by Wall Street analysts.  Nvidia shares fell by about 2.5% in aftermarket trading, because of a narrow miss of revenues forecasts for its data-center business.

raw.headline: Nvidia Breaks Sales Record Despite Chinese Trade Hiccups
raw.summary: Nvidia  set fresh sales records, as the world’s most valuable publicly traded company continued to capitalize on strong demand for AI computing power and shrugged off uncertainty surrounding its business in China.  The company predicted revenue of $54 billion for the third quarter, slightly higher than consensus estimates by Wall Street analysts.  Nvidia shares fell by about 2.5% in aftermarket trading, because of a narrow miss of revenues forecasts for its data-center business.

headline: Nvidia stock slips, Q2 data center revenue disappoints
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) reported second quarter adjusted earnings per share of $1.05 compared to a $1.01 estimate. Revenue was $46.7 billion, which was just above the Bloomberg estimate of $46.2 billion. Data center revenue was slightly below estimates, $41.1 billion versus an expected $41.29 billion. The company said in the release that "there were no H20 sales to China-based customers in the second quarter." For Q3, the chip giant sees revenue at $54.0 billion, plus or minus 2%, saying it "has not assumed any H20 shipments to China in the outlook." The company also announced an additional $60 billion stock buyback. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

raw.headline: Nvidia stock slips, Q2 data center revenue disappoints
raw.summary: Nvidia (NVDA) reported second quarter adjusted earnings per share of $1.05 compared to a $1.01 estimate. Revenue was $46.7 billion, which was just above the Bloomberg estimate of $46.2 billion. Data center revenue was slightly below estimates, $41.1 billion versus an expected $41.29 billion. The company said in the release that "there were no H20 sales to China-based customers in the second quarter." For Q3, the chip giant sees revenue at $54.0 billion, plus or minus 2%, saying it "has not assumed any H20 shipments to China in the outlook." The company also announced an additional $60 billion stock buyback. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: No Surprises In Nvidia’s (NASDAQ:NVDA) Q2 Sales Numbers But Inventory Levels Increase
summary: Leading designer of graphics chips Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) met Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, with sales up 55.6% year on year to $46.74 billion. The company expects next quarter’s revenue to be around $54 billion, close to analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.05 per share was 4% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Nvidia Stock Falls After Earning Beat
summary: Nvidia reported solid earnings late Wednesday and provided a revenue forecast for the October quarter that was above expectations.  For its July quarter, the chip maker reported adjusted earnings per share of $1.05, compared to Wall Street’s consensus estimate of $1.01, according to FactSet.  Revenue for the fiscal second quarter was $46.7 billion, ahead of analysts' expectations for $46.05 billion.

headline: Nvidia forecasts higher revenue as China clouds future
summary: (Reuters) -Nvidia forecast third-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates on Wednesday, helped by robust demand for its artificial intelligence chips from cloud providers expanding infrastructure to power generative AI technology.  The company said it has not assumed any shipments of its H20 chips to China in the outlook.  Nvidia shares have gained more than a third so far in 2025, outpacing the benchmark S&P 500 Index's year-to-date rise of nearly 10%.

raw.headline: Nvidia forecasts higher revenue as China clouds future

The company said it has not assumed any shipments of its H20 chips to China in the outlook.  Nvidia shares have gained more than a third so far in 2025, outpacing the benchmark S&P 500 Index's year-to-date rise of nearly 10%.

headline: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries says CHIPS Act framework does not involve equity
summary: (Reuters) -GlobalFoundries said on Wednesday its CHIPS Act funding is "well intact" and the framework does not involve any type of equity, days after the U.S. government took a 10% equity stake in chipmaker Intel.  Speaking at the Deutsche Bank Technology Conference, the company's finance chief, John Hollister, said the company is receiving government funding under the act according to its milestone completion.  The government's move to take a 10% stake in Intel last week sparked questions about the outlook for corporate America after U.S. President Donald Trump said he plans to do other similar deals.

headline: Exiger Wins AI Company of the Year in STEVIE® Awards for Technology Excellence
summary: Exiger, the market-leading supply chain AI company and largest provider of supply chain technology to the U.S. Federal Government, has been named a winner of the Silver® Award for Artificial Intelligence Company of the Year in the second annual Stevie Awards for Technology Excellence. Exiger was recognized alongside fellow enterprise software and advanced technology leaders, including Amazon / Amazon Web Services, Google, IBM, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia, Oracle, Salesforce, and ServiceNow.

headline: US not eyeing stake in Nvidia, Treasury Secretary Bessent says
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -A U.S. stake in chipmaker Nvidia is "not on the table" Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Wednesday.  "I don't think Nvidia needs financial support, so that seems not on the table right now," he said in an interview on Fox Business' "Mornings with Maria" program.  Bessent raised the possibility that the administration could take stakes in other industries.

Bessent raised the possibility that the administration could take stakes in other industries.
